variant.question: Routine meteorological observations made by an aircraft in the cruise at FL100 are done:

options.text: Either by the pilot or the aircraft.
Automatically by the aircraft if datalink equipped.
Manually by the pilot on VHF voice radio.
Manually by the pilot on datalink.

variant.question: An aircraft is 300 NM from its destination and the pilot is concerned about possible low cloud formation affecting the approach. How should he/she be able to obtain the most accurate forecast now, for an arrival in one hour?

options.text:
| Ask the flight information service to check if the TAF has been amended. |  |
| ------------------------------------------------------------------------ |  |

| Call on the aerodrome ATIS frequency to request a forecast on hand. |  |
| ------------------------------------------------------------------- |  |

| Listen to the report transmitted on the VOLMET broadcast. |  |
| --------------------------------------------------------- |  |

variant.question: When are you exempted from making meteorology reports?

options.text: When you did not LOGON to CPDLC.
If you are flying in uncontrolled airspace.
When your aircraft is ADS-C equipped, unless ATC requests you.
Never.

variant.question: While crossing a large mountain range, you encounter moderate turbulence. Is there an obligation to report this?

options.text: No, pilots are not obliged to report on weather conditions. However, if the conditions could affect the safety of other aircraft the pilot can decide to provide a report via voice communication.
If an air-ground data link is available, a special aircraft observation must be reported. If only voice communication is available no report should be made, to avoid frequency congestion.
Yes, a special aircraft observation shall be made by air-ground datalink. Where air-ground data link is not available it shall be reported via voice communication.
No. Reporting is obligatory in case of severe turbulence, or in case of severe mountain wave associated with moderate turbulence.

variant.question: What is the measured unit for atmospheric pressure and the computed and reported unit for QNH and QFE?

options.text: hPa
atm
mmHg
psi

variant.question: The flight crew intends to monitor latest weather information for the destination and alternate airports. The ATIS frequency is 130.880 MHz and the Air Force VOLMET frequency is 5,450 kHz. The frequency bands of the ATIS and VOLMET respectively are...

options.text: Very high (VHF) and ultra-high (UHF).
High (HF) and high (HF).
Very high (VHF) and high (HF).
High (HF) and very high (VHF).

variant.question: A pilot is flying an aircraft which is not fitted with ACARS. How can the pilot obtain routine weather reports (METARs) for specific airports?

options.text: Maintain listening watch on the AFIS frequency.
Enquire via voice on the frequency allocated to ATIS.
Maintain listening watch on the VOLMET frequency.
Request SIGMET on the international guard frequency.

variant.question: How can aviation routine weather reports (METAR) of specific airports be obtained by aircraft in flight?

options.text: AFIS
ATIS
VOLMET
SIGMET

variant.question: An aircraft is cruising at FL200\. How often is it required to transmit automated weather reports?

options.text: Required every 15 minutes.
Not required, but recommended above FL290.
Required every 30 minutes.
Not required below FL290.

variant.question:
What is correct regarding the following D-ATIS?

WSSS DEP ATIS F   
 0230 METAR   
 EXP ILS APCH SEGREGATED PARL OPS IN USE   
 ARR RWY 02L DEP 02C   
 JUNCTION OF TWY EP AND A3 INCLUDING RAPID EXIT TWY E3 SOUTHBOUND CLSD DUE WIP

WIND 010 04 KT GUST 23 WIND DIR 320 V 040   
 10 KM FEW 1600 FT   
 T 27/DP 26 QNH 1012 NOSIG   
 ARR TO ACK INFO F WITH APP ON 120.3 AND DEP WITH DELIVERY ON 121.65

options.text: A wind shear warning is in force for departure information F; wind direction is 010°, variable between 320° and 040°, and wind speed is 4 kt.
The ATIS message is based on the 0230Z METAR; some taxiways are closed due to work in progress.
Runway 02C is in use for departures; information F is available for all traffic on 121.65 MHz.
Dew point is 26° C; information F is available for all traffic on 120.3 MHz.

variant.question: When approaching the destination airfield, the pilot is listening to the broadcast ATIS message. Regarding clouds, assuming there are no CBs reported, what will this ATIS message report?

options.text: Information about all clouds in the TMA concerned.
Clouds below 1500 m (5000 ft) or below the highest minimum sector altitude, whichever is greater.
Only clouds below 1500 m (5000 ft).
All clouds at all altitudes in the vicinity of the destination airfield, and in areas where approach procedures are defined.

variant.question: LSGG 241420Z 21001KT 2200 SN FEW003 BKN010 01/00 Q1020 BLSN Which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: Visibility 2200 meters, broken 10000 FT, QFE 1020.
Wind direction 210 degrees magnetic and speed of 10 knots, QFE 1020.
Wind direction 210 degrees true and speed of 10 knots, QNH 1020.
Visibility 2200 meters, QNH 1020, blowing snow.

variant.question: An aircraft is climbing to FL200\. How often is it required to transmit automated weather reports?

options.text: Required every 30 minutes.
Required every 15 minutes.
Not required, but recommended above FL290.
Required every 30 seconds.

variant.question: If an aircraft reports to ATC that they are encountering "severe turbulence", this report is classified as which of the following?

options.text: An air turbulence report.
A special aircraft observation.
A routine aircraft oservation.
A non-routine aircraft observation.

variant.question: Which of the following is correct concerning a METAR?

options.text: The reported visibility is the minimum observed around the horizon.
Observations are made at intervals of 20 minutes.
The only cloud type required to be reported is cumulonimbus.
Wind direction is reported in degrees true.

variant.question: You are cruising at FL290\. Your aircraft is equipped with all the necessary equipment, ADS-B and a mode-S transponder. How frequent are the automatic weather broadcasts?

options.text: Every 30 seconds.
Every 15 minutes.
Not required, as automatic weather broadcasts are only required during climb.
Not required, as automatic weather broadcasts are only required above FL290.

variant.question: In aerodrome weather reports, the term "CAVOK" indicates that the visibility is or greater than…

options.text: visibility 10 km or more, no significant clouds below 5 000 feet/GND, no weather of significance
visibility 10 km or more, no significant clouds below 1 500 feet/GND, no weather of significance
visibility more than 5 000 m, no significant clouds below 1 500 m/GND, no weather of significance
visibility more than 8 km, no significant clouds below 3 000 feet/GND, no weather of significance

variant.question:
Bristol D-ATIS A, 1120 UTC. Arrival RWY 20R, departure RWY 02L. CAUTION: Work in Progress on apron area. QNH 1005 hPa. Acknowledge receipt information A on first contact with approach. Contact approach on frequency 122.525 and departure on frequency 118.3\. End of D-ATIS A.

What is the D-ATIS part referred to as “other essential operational information”?

options.text: APPROACH FREQUENCY 122.525.
QNH 1005 hPa.
DEPARTURE RWY 02L, ARRIVAL RWY 20R.
WORK IN PROGRESS ON APRON AREA.

variant.question: Air Traffic Control may require an aircraft to make routine meteorological reports of air temperature, wind direction and speed, and any icing or turbulence experienced. During climb an aircraft with data link communication equipment are:

options.text: Expected to report every 30 seconds during the climb-out phase for the first 10 minutes of the flight.
Obliged to report every 30 minutes, regardless of the aircraft’s position.
Required to report at a normal ATS reporting point, approximately every 30 minutes.
Exempt from the need to make such reports unless specifically required by ATC.

variant.question:
The pilot of an aircraft approaching UUDY asks ATC for the latest RVR. Based on the current METAR, what is the controller’s response?  
UUDY 291200Z 14006G11MPS 0600 R14/1400U FG SCT010 OVC020 03/M04 Q1003.

options.text: RVR runway one four 1400 meter doward tendency
RVR runway one four 1400 meter will rise during next 2 hours
RVR runway one four 1400 meter unchanged
RVR runway one four 1400 meter upward tendency

variant.question:
An aircraft is approaching Otopeni, the destination aerodrome, and has received the following ATIS broadcast.What is the runway in use for arrivals and on which frequency will you contact approach?

‘’OTOPENI INFORMATION OSCAR.   
 TIME 12:50   
 EXPECT AN ILS APPROACH.   
 ARRIVALS RUNWAY 08 RIGHT. DEPARTURES RUNWAY 08 LEFT   
 TRANSITION ALTITUDE 4000 FT.   
 WORK IN PROGRESS ON APRON TWO.   
 SURFACE WIND 250, 14 KNOTS.   
 VISIBILITY 10 KILOMETRES OR MORE.   
 SCATTERED 2400 FEET, BROKEN 4600 FEET.   
 CUMULONIMBUS DETECTED.   
 TEMPERATURE +19, DEW POINT +4\.   
 QNH 1007   
 NO SIGNIFICANT CHANGE   
 ACKNOWLEDGE RECEIPT OF INFORMATION OSCAR WITH APP ON 119.415\.   
 DEPARTURE WITH DELIVERY ON 121.955.‘’

options.text: RWY 08R, frequency 119.415
RWY 08R, frequency 121.955
RWY 08L, frequency 119.415
RWY 08L, frequency 121.955

variant.question: Consider the following METAR:LFPG 150505Z 27015KT 9999 SCT016 OVC024 M09/M12 Q1006 NOSIG. Which option is correct?

options.text: The time of the report is 15:05 UTC, there are scattered clouds at 1600 ft AMSL, and the dew point is 9° Fahrenheit.
The wind is westerly at 15 kt, the temperature is 9° Celsius below zero, and the QNH is 7 hPa less than ISA (International Standard Atmosphere).
Visibility is greater than 10 km, the cloud base is at 2400 ft, and the temperature is 6° Celsius less than ISA (International Standard Atmosphere).
The time of the report is 05:05 UTC, the temperature is 9° Celsius, and the weather is expected to remain the same.

variant.question: An aircraft that encounters certain meteorological phenomena in flight must make a special report. Which of the following must be reported?

options.text: Light icing experienced by the aircraft.
An isolated thunderstorm seen close to track.
Light turbulence experienced by the aircraft.
A heavy sandstorm seen some distance from track.

variant.question: A pilot is flying a scheduled international commercial air transport flight, climbing to FL100\. The aircraft is equipped with all the necessary communication and navigation equipment. Weather conditions at the moment are moderate to severe icing. When shall auto-reports be made?

options.text: These are not required below FL195.
Required every 30 seconds.
Required every 15 minutes.
Not required, but should be made for the first 10 minute in cruise.

variant.question: What weather phenomena should you report to ATC?

options.text: Streak of Altostratus clouds in front of you.
Isolated CB.
Big sandstorm left of track.
Light turbulence.

variant.question:
What is the correct option about the following D-ATIS?   
  
 WSSS Dep ATIS F   
 0130 METAR   
 Exp ILS Apch segregrated PARL Ops in use   
 ARR RWY 02L DEP 02C   
 Taxiing guidance lights on all taxiways are on for lighting inspection   
 Junction of TWY EP and A3 including rapid exit TWY E3 Southbound CLSD due WIP   
 Wind 010 04 KT GUST 23 WIND DIR 320 V 040   
 10 KM FEW 1600 FT   
 T 27 / DP 26 QNH 1012 NOSIG   
 ARR to ACK INFO E with APP on 120.3 and DEP with DELIVERY on 121.65

options.text: The ATIS is for an aerodrome with ICAO code WSSS; taxiway E3 southbound is closed; clouds reported are FEW at 1 600 ft.
Runway 02L is in use for departures; visibility is 10 km or more; wind direction is 010° and wind speed is 4 kt.
ATIS message F is current; the temperature is 26° C; and no significant changes are expected regarding weather conditions in the next two hours.
The ATIS is for departing and arriving traffic; Runway 02C is in use for departures; departures have to acknowledge they have received information F with Approach Control.

variant.question: When the term "Broken" is used in an aviation routine weather report (METAR), what is the amount of cloud covering the sky?

options.text: 1 to 4 octas.
8 octas below 10000 feet.
Clear sky below 5000 feet.
5 to 7 octas.

variant.question: Approaching your destination, you need to set the appropriate ATIS frequency in order to receive relevant weather and airfield operation information. What does ATIS stand for?

options.text: Air traffic information service
Automatic terminal information service
Area transmitting information service
Airport traffic information service

variant.question:
Who or what is required to send automated aircraft routine meteorological observations when on the cruise at FL 100?

1\. the pilot, by voice communication,  
2\. the aircraft, if it is equipped with air-ground data-link capabilities,  
3\. the pilot, using air-ground data link capabilities.

options.text: 1 and 2.
2 and 3.
2 only.
3 only.

variant.question:
An aircraft is approaching Otopeni, the destination aerodrome, and has received the following ATIS broadcast. What is the additional information in the following ATIS?

‘’OTOPENI INFORMATION OSCAR.   
 TIME 12:50   
 EXPECT AN ILS APPROACH.   
 ARRIVALS RUNWAY 08 RIGHT. DEPARTURES RUNWAY 08 LEFT   
 TRANSITION ALTITUDE 4000 FT.   
 WORK IN PROGRESS ON APRON TWO.   
 SURFACE WIND 250, 14 KNOTS.   
 VISIBILITY 10 KILOMETRES OR MORE.   
 SCATTERED 2400 FEET, BROKEN 4600 FEET.   
 CUMULONIMBUS DETECTED.   
 TEMPERATURE +19, DEW POINT +4\.   
 QNH 1007   
 NO SIGNIFICANT CHANGE   
 ACKNOWLEDGE RECEIPT OF INFORMATION OSCAR WITH APP ON 119.415\.   
 DEPARTURE WITH DELIVERY ON 121.955.‘’

options.text: WORK IN PROGRESS ON APRON TWO.
ACKNOWLEDGE RECEIPT OF INFORMATION OSCAR WITH APP ON 121.955.
WORK IN PROGRESS ON RWY TWO.
ARRIVALS RUNWAY 08 LEFT. DEPARTURES RUNWAY 08 RIGHT.

variant.question: What unit(s) of measurement shall be used for surface wind speed in aerodrome weather reports in accordance with ICAO Annex 3?

options.text: Statute miles per hour (MPH) or natural units.
Metres per second (m/s) or knots (kt).
Kilometres per hour (km/h).
Feet per second (ft/sec).

variant.question:
An aircraft is approaching Otopeni, the destination aerodrome, and has received the following ATIS broadcast. What is the runway in use for departures and on which frequency will you contact delivery?   
  
 ‘’OTOPENI INFORMATION OSCAR.   
 TIME 12:50   
 EXPECT AN ILS APPROACH.   
 ARRIVALS RUNWAY 08 RIGHT. DEPARTURES RUNWAY 08 LEFT   
 TRANSITION ALTITUDE 4000 FT.   
 WORK IN PROGRESS ON APRON TWO.   
 SURFACE WIND 250, 14 KNOTS.   
 VISIBILITY 10 KILOMETRES OR MORE.   
 SCATTERED 2400 FEET, BROKEN 4600 FEET.   
 CUMULONIMBUS DETECTED.   
 TEMPERATURE +19, DEW POINT +4\.   
 QNH 1007   
 NO SIGNIFICANT CHANGE   
 ACKNOWLEDGE RECEIPT OF INFORMATION OSCAR WITH APP ON 119.415\.   
 DEPARTURE WITH DELIVERY ON 121.955.‘’

options.text: RWY 08L, frequency 121.955
RWY 08R, frequency 121.955
RWY 08R, frequency 119.415
RWY 08L, frequency 119.415
